ac-medqa-ext-212.subjective:
• Patient: 75-year-old male
• HPI: The patient reports coming in for his annual blood pressure check-up. He has a history of hypertension and knee osteoarthritis. For his osteoarthritis, he occasionally takes acetaminophen. The patient mentions occasional knee pain but has no other complaints. He follows a diet rich in vegetables and exercises daily. Additionally, he has a family history of hematologic malignancy in a brother who died at the age of 84.
• Primary Symptom: Occasional knee pain
• PMH: Hypertension, Knee osteoarthritis
• Social Hx: Non-smoker, exercises daily, and follows a vegetable-rich diet.
• ROS: No additional complaints or symptoms noted.
ac-medqa-ext-212.objective:
• Vital Signs: Temperature: 36.8℃ (98.2℉) | Blood Pressure: 125/85 mm Hg | Heart Rate: Normal | Respiratory Rate: Normal
• Musculoskeletal Examination: Knees: Reduced range of motion and crepitus noted in both knees indicating osteoarthritis.
• Complete Blood Count: Hemoglobin: 15 g/dL | Leukocyte Count: 58,000/mm3 (markedly elevated) | Platelet Count: 250,000/mm3
• Flow Cytometry: Absolute Lymphocyte Count: 50,000/mm3, indicating a lymphocytosis

ac-medqa-ext-213.subjective:
• Patient: 30-year-old female
• HPI: The patient reports that the diarrhea has been intermittently present for the past month, with the stool often being loose and associated with blood. She mentions experiencing lower abdominal pain along with the diarrhea. She denies any recent travel history. She works at a nursing home as a caretaker and is not currently on any medications.
• Primary Symptom: Intermittent diarrhea
• Secondary Symptoms: Blood in stool, Lower abdominal pain
• PMH: No significant past medical history.
• Social Hx: Works as a caretaker in a nursing home, denies use of tobacco, alcohol, and recreational drugs.
• ROS: Denies fever, weight loss, vomiting, night sweats, recent travel, or sick contacts.
ac-medqa-ext-213.objective:
• Vital Signs: Temperature: 37.0°C (98.6°F) | Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg | Heart Rate: 75 bpm | Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths/min
• Abdominal Examination: Inspection: No visible abnormalities. | Auscultation: Normal bowel sounds. | Percussion: Tympanic throughout, no evidence of ascites. | Palpation: Mild tenderness in the suprapubic region, no rebound tenderness, or guarding. No organomegaly.
• Complete Blood Count: WBC: 11,000 /μL (slightly elevated) | Hemoglobin: 13.2 g/dL | Platelets: 240,000 /μL
• Stool Culture and Sensitivity: No pathogenic organisms isolated.
• Colonoscopy: Findings: Patchy erythema and ulceration seen in the cecum, ascending, descending, and sigmoid colon.
• Mucosal Biopsy: Findings: Colonic crypts with lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates.

ac-medqa-ext-214.subjective:
• Patient: 77-year-old male
• HPI: The patient reports the recent appearance of several brown, greasy, seemingly superficial lesions on his forehead. He mentions they appeared a few weeks ago and has not noticed any recent changes in size or color. He attempted to scrape them off, assuming they were dirt or a smear, but they persisted. No itching or pain is associated with the lesions.
• Primary Symptom: Brown, greasy-appearing lesions on forehead
• Secondary Symptoms: Attempts to remove lesions unsuccessful, No associated pain or itching
• PMH: Hypertension, controlled with medication. No history of skin cancer or chronic skin diseases.
• Social Hx: Retired school teacher. Non-smoker. Enjoys gardening and spends time outdoors.
• ROS: Denies weight loss, fever, night sweats, or any recent illnesses.
ac-medqa-ext-214.objective:
• Vital Signs: Temperature: 36.8°C (98.2°F) | Blood Pressure: 135/85 mmHg | Heart Rate: 72 bpm | Respiratory Rate: 14 breaths/min
• Dermatological Examination: Inspection: Multiple well-defined, round to oval, brown, greasy plaques ranging from 0.5 to 1.5 cm in diameter located predominantly on the forehead. | Palpation: Lesions are slightly raised, with a waxy texture. No tenderness or warmth on palpation. | Dermoscopy: Not available but typically shows cerebriform pattern and milia-like cysts in seborrheic keratoses.
• Skin Biopsy: Histopathology: Not performed but would show proliferation of benign keratinocytes, horn cysts, and a papillomatous surface if done.
